title: Scottish independence: Poll shows yes side in the lead - as it happened | UK news | The Guardian
summary: osborne : more devolved powers to be offered .

text: the secretary of state for scotland , alistair carmichael , sought to play down the significance of the latest poll findings .
the deputy leader of the scottish liberal democrats said : i have said all along that this was a wide open contest and that nobody should be taking a single vote , let alone the outcome for granted .
the only poll that actually matters is the one on september 18 and that 's the one on which i am completely focused .

he told bbc radio 5 live 's pienaar 's politics : i think there 's a really positive case for saying that scotland is already a prosperous nation and we 're a prosperous nation , we 're part of the fastest growing economy in the g7 group of nations because we are part of the uk .

documents.title: salmond : 'westminster elite ' is bluffing
text: the yes side remains the underdog because last night 's yougov poll is just one among a number and pro-independence campaigners have not relied on polls , according to scotland 's first minister , alex salmond .

appearing in the last half an hour on bbc one 's sunday politics scotland he said that things were moving firmly in the yes direction and it was because of a total lack of confidence in the westminster elite '' .

asked about news that plans to devolve more powers to scotland in the event of a no vote are going to be unveiled in the coming days , salmond said the credibility of that was undermined because david cameron was not prepared to allow those powers to be offered to scottish voters on ballot papers .
he added : what this is is a reaction to the movement on the ground and in particular the first opinoin poll showing yes in the lead .
asked if the yes campaign was still the underdog , he replied : yes we have been underdogs throughout this campaign and we are fighting from this position .
it 's one poll and we have not relied on opinion polls through out this campaign .
we are relying on persuading our fellow citizens that a radical new constitutional deal is available .
we are out campaigning on that .

it 's that positive message that is winning that campaign and we will continue to fight asked by interviewer gordon brewer if the scottish government needed to rethink its strategy on currency after comments by george osborne earlier ruling out a currency union , salmond said that the developments on the constitution proved that the london-based parties were bluffing on fiscal matters as well .
clearly they have been bluffing on the constitution .
now we are told that was a bluff and they have a different set of proposals which they are going to announce this week .
if they were prepared to bluff on the central issue of the scottish parliament then they are prepared to bluff on others .
i 'm going to wrap the blog now .
enjoy your sunday .

here 's the observer 's take on whether alex salmond would have to step down as scotland 's first minister in the event of a no vote : the 59-year-old has said he wants to serve out his term as first minister .
the snp achieved 45 % of the vote in 2011 , and remains ahead in holyrood polls .
a recent ipsos mori poll put his satisfaction rating at 49 % .
but he has spent his political career fighting for independence and some may think the honourable thing to do would be to step aside .
should the no vote be high , his handling of the debate would be called into question .
the most likely outcome is that the result is close , salmond stays on but passes leadership of the snp to his deputy , nicola sturgeon .
there are lots more answers in the piece to questions such as will there ever be another referendum ? ''
prime minister david cameron and scottish first minister alex salmond meet on the steps of st andrews house prior to their meeting to set out independence referendum deal on october 15 , 2012 .
macnicol/getty images

a piece in the observer answering a series of basic questions about the referendum and how the process will work has this on what the implications for cameron ( and labour ) of a yes vote : a yes would be a disaster for both the tories and labour , but in very different ways .
the tories have always prided themselves on the being the party of the union , despite their dwindling support north of the border in recent years .
for david cameron to be the prime minister who presided over its break-up of the union would be a humiliation .
although he has made clear he would not resign , his authority would be weakened .
with the uk facing an in/out referendum on eu membership , cameron could be the pm who leads us out of the union and out of the eu .
but there would be an upside for tories - the nightmare consequence of a yes vote for labour .
an independent scotland would massively hit labour 's chances of a commons majority after 2015 .
at the last election , 41 of the 59 scottish seats were won by labour .
just one went to the tories .
osborne played down speculation that prime minister david cameron could be forced to resign in the event of a yes vote .
this is not about the future of the british government in westminster .
this is not about the future of myself or david cameron or anyone else .

the sunday newspapers today carry reports of unease among tories , with the sunday times saying that several of the party 's mps are prepared to go public and demand that he quit and two ministers warning colleagues that they would also feel compelled to resign in the event of a yes vote .
it 's also not just cameron who , many expect , would come under pressure .
matt chorley ( @ mattchorley ) if scotland votes yes , it will be devastating for the uk .
cameron , miliband and clegg will face calls to resign .
few bigger decisions
osborne also said sharing the currency after independence would be equivalent to a couple divorcing but retaining the same bank account .
he said : no ifs , no buts .
we will not share the pound if scotland separates from the rest of the uk .

the chancellor said it was clear '' scotland wanted more autonomy and the tories , labour and the liberal democrats had agreed to deliver '' on that , adding : you will see in the next few days a plan of action to give more powers to scotland .
more tax powers , more spending powers , more plans for powers over the welfare state .
that will be put into effect - the timetable for delivering that will be put into effect the moment there is a no vote in the referendum .
the clock will be ticking for delivering those powers , and then scotland will have the best of both worlds .
they will both avoid the risks of separation but have more control over their own destiny , which is where i think many scots want to be .

documents.title: osborne : more devolved powers to be offered
text: the chancellor , george osborne , has said that the final touches were being put to proposals for much greater '' fiscal autonomy and tax-raising abilities for scotland .

the plans to devolve more powers to scotland inside the uk will be unveiled within days , according to osborne who insisted the yougov poll for the sunday times - which found pro-independence campaign ahead by 51 % to 49 % - should galvanise those who wanted to keep the union together .
speaking on the bbc 's andrew marr show , the chancellor denied that dire warnings about the dangers of splitting up had backfired : this country faces a very , very big choice .
scotland faces a very big choice .
if people were in any doubt that they can stay at home , that they do n't need to go out to the polls and vote no to avoid separation , they wo n't be in that doubt today .

they should also be in no doubt about the consequences of this decision - one of which is that scotland will not be sharing the pound as an independent country with the rest of the uk if the separatists win the vote .
there 's also another international perspective - this time from irish writer fintan o'toole - in the sunday herald .
for him , what 's most interesting about the possibility of scottish independence is not that scotland might become a new state , but that it might become a new kind of state '' .

for independence to be meaningful , scotland would have to start with an acknowledgement that many of the things to which it appeals - the power of government , the legitimacy of democratic institutions , the equality of ­citizens - are in crisis .
they can not be assumed , they have to be radically reinvented .
he divides opinion but there 's no denying noam chomsky makes certain people stop and listen .
here he is giving his views on scottish independence in a video interview posted yesterday on the bella calledonia blog .
asked how scottish independence is likely to be perceived elsewhere , he says that international capital is n't going to like '' and adds that there may be some harsh reactions '' .
noam chomsky on the scottish independence referendum .
from twitter this morning ( and last night ) , here is some more reaction to the latest developments : andrew neil ( @ afneil ) murdoch/scot independence .
he thinks hacking scandal was revenge of british establishment on him .
break up of britain would be his revenge kenny macaskill snp ( @ kennymacaskill ) no devo max on ballot .
no new powers in queens speech .
first poll with yes in lead and new powers .
aye right .
heard it and lied too afore .
hugo rifkind ( @ hugorifkind ) voters in indy scotland will have an eu vote but no westminster vote .
which parliament is likely to affect their lives more ?
scottish labour ( @ scottishlabour ) `` our values are always that working people are better together '' - @ twitterid on murnaghan # indyref # labourno

here 's an interesting piece by polling analyst mark smithson , who says that a problem over the course of the referendum campaign is that there has only been a trickle of polling data coming through , with just two published surveys being completed before saturday 's night 's dramatic yougov poll since mid-august .
this means that while the surveys there have been are having a huge impact there has been little to compare them with .
whenever a pollster such as yougov reports huge swings then similar findings from other firms can add confidence .
but just wait for the next week , when smithson expects to see a plethora of surveys from five or six firms .
he adds : the ones i am looking out for are tns-bmrb , expected on wednesday , and ipsos-mori because their fieldwork is not carried out online .

documents.title: press review
text: sunday times 'yes leads in scots poll shock ' is the splash headline in the sunday times , which also uses a of the queen and prince charles beside its front page story .

underneath a sub head stating 'unionist queen ' fears break-up of uk '' , it also says : buckingham palace aides revealed the queen 'has a great deal of concern ' about the prospect of scotland breaking away and has asked for daily updates on the progress of the campaign . ''

electionista ( @ electionista ) front page of tomorrow 's sunday times : the observer the people of scotland are to be offered a historic opportunity to devise a federal future for their country before next year 's general election , reports the observer in its splash , which says that an announcement is expected within days on plans to allow people from all parts of scottish society to decide how to finish the job '' of devolving powers from london to holyrood .

the guardian ( @ guardian ) the observer front page , sunday 7 september 2014 : shock new poll says scots set to vote yes to independence scotland on sunday 'breakthrough : yes ahead for first time ' reports scotland on sunday , up on the yougov poll .
it also says that the results came in as scotland 's first minister , alex salmond , was coming under pressure to say whether he would support military action against islamic state militants .
sunday herald a full front page graphic states : '51 49 ' under yes surges ahead '' and also leads into a report on a panelbase poll showing an increase for yes among women .

( that panelbase poll puts support for yes on 48 percent and no on 52 percent , once undecideds are out ) the mail on sunday on its front page , the mail reports that the union was hanging in the balance '' after the yes campaign emerged ahead in the yougov poll .

the story also reports on expectations of a deal on a federal future for scotland , adding : amid signs of panic and recriminations in the no ranks , the latest devolution plan could come before next year 's general election .
the scottish sun on sunday 'ayes front ' is the front page headline in the sun on sunday , which says : scotland will vote to go it alone on september 18 , a sensational new indy poll predicts '' .
it quotes an snp insider '' as saying : the momentum is clearly with yes , but we still need to work flat out . ''

the sunday telegraph the yougov poll appears to have come out too late to be up on the edition of the sunday telegraph i 'm looking at , but it has a piece inside by andrew gilligan in which he writes : an anti english racists group linked to scotland 's yes campaign is behind some of the organised intimidation which drove a prominent no supporter of the streets . ''
the sunday mail while the sunday mail does n't cover referendum developments on its front page , inside it reports on the latest poll developments under the headline 'knocking at the door ' .
of the many campaigns he has covered , the observer 's chief political commentator andrew rawnsley says that this is one of the most tricky to call .

in a piece for the observer today , he writes : the hard-to-predict elements include the missing million '' : the people who never or rarely vote at an election , but who are expected to come out in large numbers for the referendum .
the nationalists think that ought to help them and i am told the first returns from postal voting suggest an extremely high turnout .
another factor hard to gauge is the number of shy noes '' - scots too embarrassed to say that they are going to vote against independence for fear of being seen as unpatriotic .
the opinion pollsters are very twitchy about getting this one wrong .

here 's the graph of the yougov poll which was being tweeted furiously last night : faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) the extraordinary graph of @ twitterid tracking of scot # indyref opinion , updated with st poll :

the campaign for scottish independence has launched a blitzkreig '' on union suppporters , according to the yougov chief executive , peter kellner , as a poll put the yes campaign in the lead for the first time .
of the latest poll , which put yes at 51 % , to 49 % for no , kellner wrote : seldom has the term 'knife-edge ' carried such lethal force .
a two-point gap is too small for us to call the outcome .
the speed and size of the collapse in the no campaign 's lead is astonishing , according to kellner , who added .
the fact that the contest is too close to call is itself remarkable , as better together seemed to have victory in the bag .
month after month , they held a steady lead , averaging no 58 % , yes 42 % .
in the past four weeks , support for the union has drained away at an astonishing rate .
the guardian 's libby brooks has filed this news story on developments after the yougov poll for the sunday times found that the yes campaign has made significant advances across four key groups .
she reports : support for independence among labour voters has leaped from 18 % four weeks ago , to 35 % today .
support among voters under 40 has risen from 39 % to 60 % , and among working-class voters from 41 % to 56 % .
women , who have consistently shown lower levels of support for independence than men , were up from 33 % to 47 % .

good morning and welcome to the guardian 's live blog on the scottish independence referendum campaign on the morning after a yougov poll for the sunday times put the yes camp ahead with 51 % to 49 % for no , excluding the do n't knows .
alistair darling , leader of the better together campaign , said the latest poll showed the referendum will go down to the wire '' .
he said : we relish this battle .
it is not the battle of britain - it is the battle for scotland , for scotland 's children and grandchildren and the generations to come .
this is a battle we will win .
deputy first minister sturgeon said intelligence from the campaign 's canvassing database showed there was a significant shift '' taking place on the ground .
she said : what we 're finding is that as people do make up their minds , they are more likely to be deciding in favour of yes .
david cameron was at balmoral on saturday night on his annual visit , where growing support for a yes vote was likely to have been raised with the queen .
